text_run.content: Fastai is also a library, but uses Pytorch under the hood
Fastai encapsulates higher level interfaces on top of Pytorch

from torch.utils.data import DataLoader

dataset = MyDataset(X_data, y_data)
loader = DataLoader(dataset, batch_size=32, shuffle=True)
for batch_X, batch_y in loader:

from torchvision import transforms

transform = transforms.Compose([
    transforms.Resize((224,224)),
    transforms.ToTensor(),
    transforms.Normalize(mean=[0.5], std=[0.5])

from torchvision.datasets import CIFAR10

train_data = CIFAR10(root="./data", train=True, transform=transform, download=True)

API in FastAI is a powerful tool for this. It allows you to easily define the data sources, splits, and the various data transformations or augmentations you want to apply. You can use built - in transformers to randomly rotate images, adjust brightness, and do other operations to increase the diversity of your training data.
These parameters are crucial for customizing your data processing.
tells how to access the data,
divide the data into training and validation sets,
is used to get the target values, and
are for applying data transformations at the item and batch levels respectively.

from fastai.vision.all import *

dblock = DataBlock(
    blocks=(ImageBlock, CategoryBlock),   # è¾“å…¥æ˜¯å›¾åƒï¼Œè¾“å‡ºæ˜¯ç±»åˆ«
    get_items=get_image_files,            # è·å–æ•°æ®çš„æ–¹æ³•
    splitter=RandomSplitter(valid_pct=0.2, seed=42),  # åˆ’åˆ†è®­ç»ƒ/éªŒè¯é›†
    get_y=parent_label,                   # æ ‡ç­¾æ¥æºï¼šæ–‡ä»¶å¤¹å
    item_tfms=Resize(224),                # å•æ ·æœ¬å˜æ¢
    batch_tfms=aug_transforms()           # æ‰¹é‡æ•°æ®å¢å¼º
)

dls = dblock.dataloaders(path, bs=32)

import torch
import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class SimpleNet(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(SimpleNet, self).__init__()
        # å®šä¹‰å±‚
        self.fc1 = nn.Linear(784, 128)   # è¾“å…¥å±‚ â†’ éšè—å±‚
        self.fc2 = nn.Linear(128, 64)    # éšè—å±‚ â†’ éšè—å±‚
        self.fc3 = nn.Linear(64, 10)     # éšè—å±‚ â†’ è¾“å‡ºå±‚

    def forward(self, x):
        # å‰å‘ä¼ æ’­
        x = F.relu(self.fc1(x))
        x = F.relu(self.fc2(x))
        x = self.fc3(x)   # è¾“å‡ºå±‚ä¸åŠ æ¿€æ´»ï¼Œäº¤ç»™ loss function
In FastAI, you can use pre - built architectures like those from the
library. You first choose a suitable architecture, then customize it according to your task. After that, you wrap it up into a
object which combines the model, data, optimizer, and loss function. This way, you can start training your model easily.

from fastai.vision.all import *

# ä½¿ç”¨ ResNet18 ä½œä¸º backbone
This is the actual neural network architecture you choose. For instance, you can use pre - trained models like
etc. These models have been trained on large - scale datasets like ImageNet, and they can be fine - tuned for your specific task.
object that you've prepared earlier using
. It contains your training, validation (and optionally test) datasets, along with information on how to pre - process and augment the data. The
takes care of things like normalizing the images according to the statistics of your dataset.
This is used to define the evaluation metrics you want to track during training and validation. For classification tasks, common metrics are
. You can pass multiple metrics as a list.
will be calculated during training and validation.
This specifies the optimizer you want to use. FastAI has several built - in optimizers like
optimizer is used instead of the default.
This is the loss function. For image classification, the default loss function is
. But if you have a specific problem, you can choose other loss functions.
These are some of the main parameters when using
in FastAI. Each one plays a crucial role in building, training, and evaluating your vision - based machine - learning models.

for epoch in range(10):  # è®­ç»ƒ 10 ä¸ª epoch
    for inputs, labels in train_loader:
        # å‰å‘ä¼ æ’­
        outputs = model(inputs)
        loss = criterion(outputs, labels)

        # åå‘ä¼ æ’­
        optimizer.zero_grad()
        loss.backward()
        optimizer.step()

from fastai.callback.tracker import EarlyStoppingCallback, SaveModelCallback

å®šä¹‰ Learner â†’ è°ƒç”¨ fit/fine_tune â†’ å¯é€‰å›è°ƒå’Œå­¦ä¹ ç‡æŸ¥æ‰¾
You pointed out that FastAI simplifies a lot compared to PyTorch. In PyTorch, you have to manually set up the optimizer, loss function, and handle backpropagation. But with FastAI's

class, you can achieve these tasks with much simpler code. Also, you're correct that FastAI makes transfer learning easy. It allows you to use pre-trained models and adapt them for your specific tasks.

model.eval()
with torch.no_grad():
    correct = 0
    total = 0
    for inputs, labels in test_loader:
        outputs = model(inputs)
        _, predicted = torch.max(outputs.data, 1)
        total += labels.size(0)
        correct += (predicted == labels).sum().item()

from fastai.interpret import ClassificationInterpretation
interp = ClassificationInterpretation.from_learner(learn)
interp.plot_top_losses(9, figsize=(7,7))   # æ˜¾ç¤ºæŸå¤±æœ€å¤§çš„æ ·æœ¬
interp.plot_confusion_matrix(figsize=(6,6)) # æ··æ·†çŸ©é˜µ
